I think you would be correct. Weren't most really long swords made for
some festival ? I recall reading about that somewhere.
 
- Matt

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...] 
Verzonden: zaterdag 3 mei 2003 2:27
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae


Hi matt, thanks fo rthat, I was meaning as a general rule, these swords
being 9 feet long are certainly not prectical for use ( the quick draw
wouldn't be too quick :-) ) I could only imagine these being made for
presentation and or a gift.

Rich
  ----- Original Message ----- 
  From: Matthew E. Hoyle 
  To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Friday, May 02, 2003 8:21 AM
  Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: O-dachi Koshirae


  "Many important military figures of the Heian and Kamakura periods
gave
  swords and armor to the shrine that have been preserved to the present
  day.  Rather than commissioning pieces to be dedicated to the shrine,
  most of what was given was the actual weapons used successfully in
  battle.  Instead of being freshly polished and remounted, the swords
  were presented "as-is" and for the most part have been retained as
they
  were received. "

  - Matt
